CN.callerid_rules: Valid caller ID required; no spoofing. **95**-prefix numbers banned for telemarketing use; carriers mark international calls with "+" or country code
CN.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is regulated under consumer protection advertising and data privacy laws; prior consent is generally required
CN.regime_b2b_text: No explicit B2B telemarketing law; personal data laws still apply if individuals are called
CN.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Treat all cold calls as consent-based. Implement an **opt-in only** model for Chinese consumer numbers. Integrate with carrier "Refuse Call" flags once available. Enforce internal DNC lists and avoid off-hours calls. Ensure a real (licensed) caller number is displayed (no "95" short-codes for marketing). Recording okay with notice. No explicit AI disclosure law yet but transparency is advisable.

dnc.name: Refuse Call Platform (谢绝来电平台) (pilot national DNC)
dnc.url: Carrier portals (e.g. donotcall.189.cn by China Telecom)

sources.title: Consumer Protection Law (ZH) Advertising Law (ZH) PIPL (ZH)

JP.callerid_rules: Telemarketer must **display a valid caller number** (no blocking); must immediately state identity & purpose at call start. No special prefix required (unlike some countries)
JP.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing sales to consumers are governed by the Specified Commercial Transactions Act (for "Telephone Solicitation Sales") and privacy laws; unsolicited calls are allowed but tightly regulated
JP.regime_b2b_text: No special B2B telemarketing law (Act covers consumers only); general business marketing is largely unregulated aside from personal data rules
JP.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** No national DNC list – but **internal opt-out** is mandatory. System should allow agents to instantly mark a number as "do-not-call" if the person refuses and no further calls to that consumer. Avoid calling outside 8am–9pm local time. Ensure caller ID is shown and agents give a proper intro. Recording okay (one-party consent) but best practice is to inform ("this call may be recorded…"). AI voices can be used; no disclosure rule but do not mislead or impersonate a human. Provide an opt-out mechanism during any automated call to comply with fair practice.

dnc.name: None (No national DNC registry for voice calls)

sources.title: Specified Commercial Transactions Act (EN) APPI (EN) Consumer Affairs Agency Guidelines (JA)

KR.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be spoofed; **telemarketers must use a valid number** and cannot hide it. No special prefix by law but calls often flagged "Advertisement" on phones. (Carriers block masked/spoofed calls under Telecom Act)
KR.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is highly regulated (Opt-out registry under **Door-to-Door Sales Act** covers telemarketing); **PIPA privacy law** also requires prior consent for marketing use of personal data
KR.regime_b2b_text: No dedicated B2B telemarketing law; **if personal data of individuals (e.g. employee mobiles) is used PIPA consent rules apply**. Pure B2B (company main lines) is generally unregulated
KR.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Must integrate with the **KFTC DNC registry** – before dialing any KR consumer number check against donotcall.go.kr (API available). Ensure **prior consent** is obtained for marketing calls (document it). Provide disclosure of data source upon request (Korean law requires telling the person how you got their number). Dial only within standard hours (8am–9pm local). Use only approved phone numbers (get a 140-type telemarketing number if available in KR). Recording can be enabled (one-party consent) and is required if selling insurance/financial products – so have recording on for those campaigns.

sources.title: KFTC DNC Registry (EN) PIPA (EN) Door-to-Door Sales Act (EN)

HK.callerid_rules: No special caller ID rules for telemarketing yet (proposed law would ban hiding number). It's best practice to display a valid Hong Kong number and identify the organization during the call. (Since 2015 incoming overseas calls show "+" prefix to help identify scams)
HK.regime_b2c_text: Direct marketing calls to consumers are governed by the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (PDPO) – marketers must notify individuals and honor opt-out requests. No blanket DNC for live calls (P2P) yet
HK.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulations (focus is on consumer personal data). Calls purely to businesses are generally permissible
HK.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** No universal DNC for live calls yet but **do NOT cold-call HK numbers without prior PDPO compliance**. Ensure you have either (a) the person's consent or (b) have given them a PDPO notice and an opportunity to opt out (e.g. via email/SMS) before calling. Maintain an internal DNC list per PDPO (if someone says "don't call me again" record and honor that). Avoid call attempts at night (common courtesy; industry practice is roughly 9am–9pm). Monitor legislative developments – a P2P DNC registry could become law; if it does integrate it immediately. AI voice calls can be used but **do not conceal identity** – start with a clear introduction as required.

sources.title: PDPO (EN) OFCA DNC Guidelines (EN) PCPD Direct Marketing Guidelines (EN)

TW.callerid_rules: Caller ID **must be displayed** – hiding number is forbidden by regulation. Telemarketers must immediately identify themselves and purpose on call start. No special prefix but consumers can verify numbers via anti-scam apps or 165 hotline
TW.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is subject to **Fair Trade Act/Consumer Protection** rules and Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA). Unsolicited calls are allowed but with strict conduct requirements
TW.regime_b2b_text: No dedicated B2B telemarketing law; if personal data of a person is used (e.g. calling an individual's mobile for business) PDPA's opt-out and notice requirements apply
TW.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Implement **per-number opt-out tracking**. Agents/scripts must inform consumers of the sales intent and **stop immediately if the consumer expresses disinterest**. Configure dialer to block any number that opted out ("拒絕行銷"). Ensure caller ID is never withheld. Allow call recording especially to capture the agreement for any sale (required to keep as proof). AI calls are not explicitly regulated but all the same rules (identification opt-out option etc.) apply. Err on the side of consent: consider obtaining explicit opt-in for marketing calls when possible due to PDPA's privacy expectations.

dnc.name: None (No national DNC list; instead an **"internal opt-out"** system mandated by law)

sources.title: Fair Trade Act (ZH) PDPA (ZH) Consumer Protection Act (ZH)

IN.callerid_rules: **Must use designated telemarketer numbers (140xx series)** for all outbound marketing calls. CLI cannot be spoofed; using personal/mobile SIMs for telemarketing is illegal (telcos will disconnect unregistered sources on complaint). All marketing SMS must use registered sender IDs and templates
IN.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is strictly regulated by TRAI's **Telecom Commercial Communications (Unsolicited Commercial Communications) rules**; prior customer consent and DND compliance are required
IN.regime_b2b_text: No separate B2B telemarketing law (the UCC regulations apply to calls/messages to subscribers mainly consumers). B2B calls are generally allowed if not to personal numbers
IN.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** **Absolutely integrate the DND list**: scrub every outbound number against India's NCPR. Only dial via registered telemarketer IDs and on **140xx numbers**. Enforce time-of-day rules (no promotional dialing between 9pm–9am India time). Implement category-based opt-outs if applicable (TRAI allows users to opt in to some categories and out of others). Obtain express consent (digitally or in writing) for any automated or bulk calling campaigns – TRAI mandates recent (within 3 months) consent for commercial calls. Recording calls isn't mandated but keep logs and recordings of consent where possible (for compliance defense). AI voice agents can be used but they must follow all rules: use approved caller ID state the business identity at start and include an opt-out (e.g. "Press 9 to unsubscribe") in the script.

dnc.name: National Customer Preference Register (NCPR) a.k.a. **"Do Not Disturb" registry**

sources.title: TRAI UCC Rules (EN) NCPR Portal (EN) DPDPA 2023 (EN)

VN.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

KH.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

LA.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

MM.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

PK.callerid_rules: No special caller ID or prefix system (unlike India). Telemarketers often use regular mobile or landline numbers; PTA warns operators to curb **SPAM CLI** and allows users to block unknown numbers via *420#. (Product should ensure valid Pakistani numbers are displayed; best practice: use identifiable numbers and avoid frequent number changes)
PK.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is addressed by PTA directives: consumers can opt out of promotional calls/SMS via the **Do Not Call Register** (since 2010s). Unsolicited marketing without consent is discouraged by the regulator
PK.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing laws known. B2B communications are generally not restricted (unless personal mobile numbers are targeted)
PK.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Enable **Pakistan DNCR compliance**: do not contact numbers that have opted out via 3627 (telecom operators likely filter such numbers – nonetheless maintain your own list of numbers to avoid). Provide a clear opt-out method in any message or call. It's advisable to get **opt-in consent** especially for bulk campaigns as Pakistan may introduce data protection soon. Limit call times to business hours/local daytime to avoid complaints. Monitor PTA guidelines – they sometimes issue new spam-control directives (e.g. forbidding masking of identities or requiring telemarketer registration). Automated/AI calls should be used sparingly and always include identification and opt-out (to avoid being flagged as spam).

dnc.name: Do Not Call Register (DNCR)
dnc.url: No public website; opt-out via SMS "reg" to 3627 (PTA service)

sources.title: PTA DNCR Guidelines (EN) PTA Anti-Spam Measures (EN)

BD.callerid_rules: No special telemarketer number series. Calls come from normal mobile or landline numbers. BTRC instructs operators to remind users about DND options monthly. CLI spoofing is illegal (general anti-fraud provisions) but no dedicated caller ID rules for telemarketers
BD.regime_b2c_text: Unsolicited marketing calls/SMS are discouraged by BTRC. **"Do Not Disturb" (DND) services** exist via mobile operators for consumers to block promos. No specific telemarketing law but general consumer protection against harassment applies
BD.regime_b2b_text: No B2B-specific rules. Telemarketing to businesses is not separately regulated
BD.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Rely on Bangladesh's carrier-level DND: if possible **obtain lists or API from carriers to scrub out DND-activated numbers** (currently each operator may handle internally – so as a precaution include an opt-out mechanism in every call/SMS and honor any opt-out request directly). Keep calls to reasonable hours. Be aware spam complaints can lead BTRC to direct operators to cut off your numbers. Aim to get explicit consent from users (e.g. via forms or SMS) before marketing calls especially as data privacy laws evolve. AI calls are not common in BD – if used ensure they clearly identify the business and provide a way to connect to a human or opt out.

dnc.name: Do Not Disturb service (per carrier per user)
dnc.url: N/A (USSD codes per operator: e.g. *121*1101# for GP)

sources.title: BTRC DND Guidelines (EN) Draft Data Protection Act (EN)

LK.callerid_rules: No specific caller ID or prefix rules. Telemarketers often use regular phone numbers. The regulator (TRCSL) has addressed call spoofing as part of fraud prevention but not specific to telemarketing. It's good practice to display a number and not withhold CLI
LK.regime_b2c_text: No specific telemarketing law but **Consumer Affairs Authority Act** and **Data Protection Act 2022** provide general safeguards. Direct marketing using personal data likely requires consent or opportunity to opt out under the new privacy law
LK.regime_b2b_text: No distinct B2B regulations. Telemarketing targeting businesses is generally permissible. The 2022 privacy law applies only to natural persons' data not to company contacts
LK.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Implement basic **opt-out handling**: allow Sri Lankan recipients to easily opt out of future calls (and honor that in your system). Given the new privacy law it's safest to use **consent-based marketing** – i.e. call people who have agreed or not objected after notice. Train agents to immediately comply if a person says they don't want marketing. Keep call times to normal hours. Because no official DNC exists err on side of caution: perhaps avoid repeatedly cold-calling non-customers. Keep an eye on any consumer protection updates – if telemarketing nuisances rise regulations could be introduced. AI voice calls should follow the same norms as human calls (clear identification etc.).

dnc.name: None (No Do Not Call list in Sri Lanka)

sources.title: Data Protection Act No. 9 of 2022 (official gazette) (EN)

NP.callerid_rules: No special caller ID rules. Using a recognizable number is recommended. (Nepal Telecom and Ncell have not implemented distinct prefixes for telemarketers)
NP.regime_b2c_text: No specific telemarketing legislation identified. Telemarketing is minimal; any marketing calls must still comply with general consumer protection (avoid harassment) and any applicable privacy principles (Nepal has draft privacy legislation)
NP.regime_b2b_text: No B2B telemarketing rules. B2B calls are generally free from regulation in Nepal
NP.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** **No clear legal framework** – proceed conservatively. Always allow recipients to opt out and maintain an internal list of "do-not-call" requests. Limit call frequency to avoid being flagged for nuisance. If Nepal enacts its data protection law (draft pending) expect a consent/opt-out requirement for using personal numbers. Until then apply basic etiquette: identify your company on calls offer a way to decline future calls and stick to local business hours. AI calls: since unregulated ensure they aren't mistaken for scams – perhaps open with a statement and route to human on request.

sources.title: (No official sources found – based on regional comparison and NTA communications)

BT.regime_b2c_text: No known telemarketing-specific laws. Telemarketing is not common; any practices would be governed by general provisions (e.g. Personal Data Law if enacted and consumer protection from harassment)
BT.regime_b2b_text: No B2B rules; B2B calls are fine
BT.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Very little formal guidance. If engaging in telemarketing in Mongolia follow best practices: get prior permission where possible introduce yourself clearly and keep an internal list of anyone who says stop. Given the lack of rules telemarketing could be seen as unusual – a gentle personalized approach is key. Keep volumes low to avoid prompting regulatory attention. AI calls are untested – if used make them sound as natural and polite as possible or prefer live agents.

sources.title: (No specific sources – inference from Mongolia's legal environment)

MV.callerid_rules: No known caller ID or prefix requirements. Use a local recognizable number for better response. (Maldives telecom providers do not distinguish telemarketing lines)
MV.regime_b2c_text: No dedicated telemarketing laws known. Marketing calls would fall under general consumer protection and the new Data Protection Act (2021) which requires consent for processing personal data
MV.regime_b2b_text: No B2B telemarketing rules. B2B calls are generally unregulated (privacy law covers personal data only)
MV.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Given the new privacy law treat Maldives as **opt-in territory**: do not cold-call individuals without prior consent. If calls are made ensure you have a lawful basis (preferably consent). There's no DNC list so manage opt-outs internally. Because the market is small unsolicited calls can cause brand damage quickly. Focus on consent-based outreach (e.g. customers who signed up). AI calls are untested here – use with caution and clearly identify the caller to avoid confusion or hang-ups.

ID.callerid_rules: No special telemarketer caller IDs. Regulators encourage carriers to label spam calls (via apps or network) but no prefix. Caller ID must not be spoofed (prohibited by law due to fraud concerns)
ID.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is subject to **general privacy law (Personal Data Protection Act 2022)** and sectoral regulations (e.g. OJK for financial marketing). No central DNC registry; consent is the emerging norm under the new PDP law
ID.regime_b2b_text: No explicit B2B telemarketing rules; if calling individuals at businesses PDP law still applies to their personal data
ID.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** After Indonesia's PDP law **do not cold-call without prior consent**. You should obtain clear consent (e.g. web form tick box) before calling Indonesian consumers. Maintain proof of consent for each contact. Ensure a privacy notice is given (if calling agents should mention how you got their number). For any call lists you had pre-law consider running a re-consent campaign. Timing: stick to local business hours. Train agents for polite handling – unwanted calls can be reported to Kominfo or Consumer Protection. Use of AI voice: not specifically banned but given low public familiarity it could be poorly received – if used immediately allow option to speak to a human. Keep recordings secure and document consent withdrawal promptly.

sources.title: Personal Data Protection Act No.27 of 2022 (ID) (ID) OJK Guidelines (EN)

MY.callerid_rules: No specific caller ID rules for telemarketers. Usually calls originate from mobile or fixed numbers. The MCMC has encouraged truthful CLI and taken action on scam call CLI spoofing but no dedicated prefix like "+AD" exists. Always display a number; do not spoof
MY.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is governed by the Personal Data Protection Act 2010 (PDPA) – which requires consent (or notice & opt-out) for direct marketing using personal data. No national DNC list but industry self-regulation exists
MY.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing law; PDPA does not apply to business contact information used for business purposes (only personal data of individuals)
MY.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Ensure **PDPA compliance**: you should have either explicit consent or have provided a privacy notice with an opt-out opportunity *before* calling Malaysian individuals. If you haven't your calls could be unlawful. A practical approach is to send an email/SMS asking permission or include consent in web sign-ups. Always allow opt-out (like an internal DNC): if someone says "don't call" mark it and don't call again. Time your calls considerately. Although no formal DNC list the PDPA opt-out right functions similarly – be ready to delete or suppress data of anyone who objects to marketing. Keep call logs to show compliance (in case of complaints to PDPC). AI voice use: permissible but ensure it follows PDPA (the call content is personal data processing); it's wise to have the AI state which company it represents and offer a human fallback.

dnc.name: None (no centralized DNC registry; companies rely on PDPA's opt-out rights)

SG.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be concealed. There's no special prefix but many marketing calls originate from mobile-prefix numbers which recipients often distrust. Under new anti-scam measures telemarketers using overseas routes must use "[+]-prefix" (this is for all overseas calls). Locally the new requirement (2023) is that spoofed local numbers are forbidden – use the number assigned to you. **In short:** use a valid SG number and don't mask CLI
SG.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is tightly regulated by the **Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)** and a robust **Do Not Call (DNC) registry**. Sending telemarketing messages or calls requires checking DNC and including certain disclosures
SG.regime_b2b_text: B2B calls are generally exempt from DNC rules **if** purely to business contact numbers for business-related marketing. (PDPA DNC covers messages to Singapore telephone numbers "addressed to individuals")
SG.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** **Must integrate SG's DNC registry**. Before any call or text to a Singapore number check if it's on DNC (unless you've obtained explicit consent within the last *likely* 12 months – PDPC recommends refreshing consent). Maintain records of consent (in case of audit). Include the organization's name and contact in call or immediately after (legal requirement). Ensure caller ID is displayed; ideally use a Singapore number to avoid "[SPAM?]" labeling. If an agent or AI reaches voicemail they should state the organization and callback info to comply with PDPC rules. Timing: stick to local waking hours to avoid "nuisance" interpretations. AI voice usage is allowed but if you use a prerecorded message **provide a way to opt-out (e.g. "press 9 to be removed")** in the call.

dnc.name: **Do Not Call Registry** (covers calls SMS fax)

sources.title: PDPA (EN) PDPC DNC Guidelines (EN) PDPC Advisory Guidelines on DNC Provisions 2021 (EN)

TH.callerid_rules: No dedicated caller ID rules for telemarketers yet. The National Telecom Commission has encouraged carriers to label spam numbers and introduced a prefix "<ADV>" tag for SMS marketing. For calls new measures in 2023 require telecom operators to display a "Scam warning" on suspicious call numbers. Telemarketers should use numbers registered in their company name; avoid frequent number changes (could be flagged)
TH.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is constrained by the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA effective 2022) which requires consent for most direct marketing and consumer protection laws against nuisance. A draft law to establish a DNC registry has been discussed but not yet enacted
TH.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing law; communications to company contacts are not explicitly regulated (PDPA covers individuals' data only)
TH.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Treat Thailand as **consent-required**. Ensure you have explicit opt-in (e.g. checked box "I agree to be contacted") before cold-calling a Thai individual. Keep proof of consent. Without consent you risk PDPC penalties. Implement internal suppression: if anyone says they didn't consent or asks not to be called stop immediately and log it. Monitor legal developments – a formal DNC list may appear; if so integrate it. Use clearly identified phone numbers (matching your company) for calls – this builds trust and avoids being auto-flagged. AI calls: Use cautiously; Thais have been hit with scam robocalls so an unfamiliar AI voice might be mistaken for a scam. If you do use an AI consider a Thai-language intro that it's an automated call from Company X and offer a human agent option.

dnc.name: None (proposed "No-Call" list is not in force yet)

sources.title: PDPA B.E.2562 (2019) (TH) Thai PDPC Guidance (EN summary)

PH.callerid_rules: No special telemarketer caller ID rules. Often calls come from mobile numbers. Telecoms have implemented caller ID tagging for spam (some networks show "Spam Likely"). The National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) has regulations against caller ID spoofing (to combat scams) but no prefix system for marketing
PH.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing is subject to the **Data Privacy Act 2012** (which requires consent or at least fair processing notice for direct marketing) and consumer protection rules on unwanted communications. No nationwide DNC registry exists yet
PH.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B provisions. Marketing to companies is generally unrestricted unless personal data is involved
PH.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Operate under the assumption of **consent required**. Ideally call only those who have opted in via web forms etc. If you must cold-call ensure you give a proper privacy notice in the call (who you are how you got their number if asked and that they can opt out). Immediately cease calling a number if the person objects – and add it to an internal DNC list. Be mindful the Philippines is very sensitive to scam calls; using an AI voice might confuse people – better to use a live agent for initial contact. Keep call times to business hours. Stay alert for a potential DNC law; if one passes compliance (scrubbing against it) will become mandatory.

sources.title: Data Privacy Act IRR 2016 (EN) NPC Advisory on Direct Marketing 2017 (EN)

MN.regime_b2c_text: No known telemarketing-specific laws. Telemarketing is not common; any practices would be governed by general provisions (e.g. Personal Data Law if enacted and consumer protection from harassment)
MN.regime_b2b_text: No B2B rules; B2B calls are fine
MN.notes_for_product: **Product Note:** Very little formal guidance. If engaging in telemarketing in Mongolia follow best practices: get prior permission where possible introduce yourself clearly and keep an internal list of anyone who says stop. Given the lack of rules telemarketing could be seen as unusual – a gentle personalized approach is key. Keep volumes low to avoid prompting regulatory attention. AI calls are untested – if used make them sound as natural and polite as possible or prefer live agents.

sources.title: (No specific sources – inference from Mongolia's legal environment)

AE.callerid_rules: Display company identity; no personal numbers; no spoofing.
AE.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

SA.callerid_rules: CLI must be truthful; anti-spoofing enforced.
SA.regime_b2c_text: Unsolicited calls/messages regulated by CST Anti-Spam framework
SA.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

QA.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

KW.regime_b2c_text: Consumer rights restrict unsolicited electronic messages (SMS/email); calls not specifically regulated
KW.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

OM.regime_b2c_text: Consumer protection & TRA complaint regime; no explicit telemarketing code
OM.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

JO.regime_b2c_text: TRC guidance on nuisance calls/SMS; no telemarketing-specific law
JO.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

LB.regime_b2c_text: General consumer/data-protection principles; no specific telemarketing statute
LB.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

IQ.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

IR.callerid_rules: Ongoing 2024–2025 actions to curb advertising calls.
IR.regime_b2c_text: CRA enforcement against promotional voice/SMS from personal numbers; no public DNC
IR.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.
IR.notes_for_product: Use registered business lines only; avoid automated/promotional voice without explicit consent; provide opt-out.

IL.regime_b2c_text: Automated calls covered by Spam Law (Amendment 40); live telemarketing constrained by national DNC
IL.regime_b2b_text: Mixed; no specific B2B telemarketing statute; Spam Law still applies to automated systems.

dnc.name: “Do Not Call Me” Registry (מאגר אל תתקשרו אליי)

YE.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

TR.regime_b2c_text: Commercial electronic messages (incl. calls) require prior consent and IYS registration
TR.regime_b2b_text: B2B to traders/merchants allowed without prior consent but must provide opt-out

AT.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be concealed (per telecom rules; no special prefix mandated).
AT.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers requires prior consent (opt-in):
AT.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is also restricted; explicit consent or clear prior indication of interest is required:
AT.notes_for_product: No DNC list for calls (only email list). Platform should obtain express consent before calling any Austrian consumer or business. Treat all cold calls as opt-in only.

BE.callerid_rules: Caller ID must be visible (anonymous calls are prohibited by Code of Economic Law). No special prefix.
BE.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is allowed only if the person has not objected or registered on the national Do Not Call list::
BE.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is similarly permitted unless the number is on the Do Not Call Me list (covers B2B and B2C):
BE.notes_for_product: Platform must integrate DNCM scrubbing for all Belgian numbers (including corporate). Apply consumer quiet hours as best practice.

dnc.name: Do Not Call Me List (Liste Ne m’appelez plus)

sources.title: Code of Economic Law, Art. XII.13

BG.callerid_rules: Caller identity must not be concealed (per Electronic Communications Act).
BG.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is prohibited without prior consent: (opt-in required)
BG.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses: presumed consent model (allowed unless objected)
BG.notes_for_product: Treat all consumer calls as requiring explicit consent. No official DNC to check

HR.callerid_rules: Caller ID must be visible; no special prefix required.
HR.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing calls to consumers are allowed only if the person has not opted out (either directly or via the national ‘Do Not Call’ registry):
HR.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is generally permitted unless the business number is registered on the opt-out list
HR.notes_for_product: Must scrub calling lists against Croatia’s ‘Ne zovi’ registry. If unsure whether a number might be residential

CZ.callerid_rules: If a subscriber listed their number publicly and did not opt out there
CZ.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers requires prior consent unless the consumer has explicitly indicated in a public directory that they welcome marketing calls:
CZ.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses also generally requires consent

dnc.name: opt-in (unless public opt-in noted)
dnc.url: None (consent managed via public phone directory preferences)

DK.callerid_rules: Denmark bans unsolicited consumer calls for most products except a few sectors (e.g. insurance
DK.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is permitted only if the consumer has not opted out via the CPR “Robinson list” (opt-out):. Certain sectors may require prior consent by law
DK.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is allowed (no specific B2B restrictions)

EE.callerid_rules: Caller must provide identity; no special number prefix required.
EE.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is allowed unless the person has opted out of such calls (opt-out; no national list):
EE.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to legal persons is allowed; generic business contacts can be used unless the entity opted out
EE.notes_for_product: Ensure any Estonian contact who says “do not call” is suppressed going forward (internal opt-out list). No centralized list to check

FI.callerid_rules: No broad exemption. Even existing customers should not be called for new offers without consent (unless falling under “closely related to job role” in B2B context).
FI.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is effectively opt-in – direct marketing calls are generally not allowed unless the consumer has given consent

dnc.name: opt-out for B2B
dnc.url: Direct Marketing Prohibition List (ASML/Robinson list for consumers)

FR.callerid_rules: Caller ID cannot be withheld. Use of mobile (06/07) or regular geographic numbers for mass outbound campaigns is prohibited for autodialers; call centers should use specific ranges (e.g. 01 62…
FR.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is heavily regulated: consumers must not be called if they are on the Bloctel opt-out list, and calls are only allowed within strict hours Mon–Fri:. In practice, prior consent is effectively required for unsolicited consumer calls (opt-out by law, but with severe constraints).
FR.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to business numbers is permitted, but the called party must have had an opportunity to object to such calls when their number was collected:. Strong identification requirements apply for call centers.
FR.notes_for_product: Art. L.223-1 Consumer Code (Bloctel):; Décret 2022-1313 (call hours)::; ARCEP Plan de Numérotation 2023:

DE.callerid_rules: Market research calls (if genuinely not sales-related) may not fall under UWG §7’s marketing call ban. However
DE.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing calls to consumers are illegal without explicit prior consent:. German law treats unsolicited calls as an aggressive practice unless the consumer has actively agreed (opt-in)
DE.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is only allowed if the individual called can be presumed to have an interest and to have implicitly consented (“presumed consent”):. Otherwise, explicit consent is required even for B2B.

sources.title: No major legislative changes since 2021. Enforcement remains strict
high-profile fines have been issued for unlawful calls. Draft laws propose even tighter controls on spoofed calls.

GR.callerid_rules: it applies even to companies they have a relationship with.
GR.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is allowed except where the consumer has opted out. Consumers can register objections (e.g. via their telecom provider) to avoid marketing calls (opt-out system):
GR.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is generally allowed; no specific B2B telemarketing provisions were found

dnc.name: No official national DNC (opt-outs handled via operators)

HU.confidence: no significant changes recently. electronic communications act and advertising act provisions still apply
HU.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing calls to consumers are allowed unless the consumer has explicitly opted out beforehand (no national list; opt-out handled case-by-case):
HU.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses faces no specific prohibition

IE.callerid_rules: Limited. Irish law allows a form of “previous business context” for email/SMS
IE.confidence: but such entities can register on ndd to opt out
IE.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers requires prior consent unless a “soft opt-in” applies (existing customer with similar product):. Live marketing calls to mobile numbers are generally prohibited without explicit consent:. All cold calls must be screened against the National Do-Not-Call list.
IE.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to corporate entities is permitted without prior consent
IE.notes_for_product: but number used should permit a return call or identification.

sources.title: Caller ID must not be withheld (PECR requirement). No special prefix mandated

IT.callerid_rules: No automatic exemption. Being a customer does not exempt a company from checking RPO:. (Companies can call recent customers for similar products under soft opt-in for email/SMS, but for calls they must still honor RPO listings.)
IT.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is regulated on an opt-out basis via the Registro Pubblico delle Opposizioni (RPO):. Telemarketers may call consumers only if they are not listed in RPO and have not otherwise objected. Specific calling hours must be respected per the industry code
IT.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to business numbers is also covered by the RPO opt-out scheme (companies can register their lines):. Marketing calls to businesses are allowed unless the number is on RPO or the business objected
IT.notes_for_product: 2024) imposes stricter rules on call times

sources.title: RPO was expanded to cover mobile numbers and businesses. A new Telemarketing Code of Conduct (effective Sept 28

LV.callerid_rules: Direct marketing rules apply only to natural persons. Calls to a number owned by a company are not considered “consumer” calls:. Individuals have the right to object at any time to further calls.
LV.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing is generally allowed if the call is made to a number that belongs to a legal entity or was made public by the individual; purely private numbers are protected (opt-out by default)
LV.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to companies (legal entities) is allowed unless the company/employee has previously opted out. Calls to publicly listed business contacts are generally permissible:
LV.notes_for_product: Information Society Services Law §9:; DPA guidance (LV)

LT.callerid_rules: “Soft opt-in” exception exists for electronic channels in context of similar products
LT.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is only allowed with prior consent (opt-in):. Unsolicited calls to individuals without consent are prohibited
LT.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to business contacts also requires consent unless an exception for existing relationships applies:. Lithuania does not differentiate strongly between consumer and business targets for calls

LU.callerid_rules: If an individual gave prior consent or their number is public in a directory without opting out
LU.confidence: no significant changes. electronic privacy act still governs (only natural persons’ communications require consent)
LU.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers requires prior consent (natural persons are protected under the Electronic Privacy Act):. Unsolicited calls to individuals are not allowed unless opted in
LU.regime_b2b_text: No specific law for B2B calls: – marketing to corporate entities is generally allowed without consent. Only calls to natural persons (consumers) require opt-in by law

MT.callerid_rules: an existing customer can be called
MT.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is allowed as long as the consumer has been given a clear chance to opt out of future calls. Essentially an opt-out regime – the first call is allowed

NL.confidence: 2021 amendment to article 11.7 of the telecommunications act introduced the consumer opt-in requirement and ended the opt-out registry
NL.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers now requires prior consent. As of 2021, cold calls to consumers are prohibited unless the consumer has explicitly opted in, or if there is a recent existing customer relationship (within 3 years) for similar products/services.
NL.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to companies (corporate subscribers) remains allowed without prior consent. However

PL.callerid_rules: explicit opt-in is strictly required for telemarketing. Enforcement by UKE is active.
PL.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing calls to consumers require prior consent by law (opt-in). Poland’s law (Telecommunications Act Art. 172) prohibits calling or sending marketing communications without the subscriber’s prior consent
PL.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to companies/entrepreneurs also generally requires consent unless perhaps calling a generic office line without personal data. Polish law does not explicitly exempt B2B calls from the consent requirement.

PT.callerid_rules: if they registered on the opt-out list or otherwise objected
PT.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is allowed unless the consumer has opted out. Portugal maintains an official opt-out list for consumers (and even legal persons) – marketers must not call numbers on this list:
PT.regime_b2b_text: No specific distinction; legal persons can also register on the opt-out list:. Generally

dnc.name: opt-out
dnc.url: Lista Nacional de Não Receção de Comunicações (Consumer General Directorate’s opt-out list)

RO.callerid_rules: legitimate_interest (one-party recording legal; must inform under GDPR)
RO.regime_b2c_text: There is no specific statute explicitly addressing live telemarketing calls to consumers. Unsolicited automated calls are explicitly forbidden without consent, but live calls fall under general data protection and fair practice rules. Marketers should obtain consent or at minimum honor any objections.
RO.regime_b2b_text: but implied by GDPR objection rights)
RO.notes_for_product: No recent legislative change. Enforcement largely through GDPR (ANSPDCP can sanction misuse of personal data in marketing).

dnc.name: no special B2B telemarketing law. Calls to companies are generally allowed
dnc.url: but any personal data use (calling a person) must respect objection rights

SK.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers requires prior consent, unless the number is publicly available and not opted out. Slovakia operates an opt-out list; if a consumer is not on that list and has publicly provided their number, calls may be made (opt-in by default, with opt-out signals considered):.
SK.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is allowed. However
SK.notes_for_product: marketers may call without separate consent:. Purely informational calls or those by certain regulated industries might not count as “marketing”.

sources.title: If a person publicly shares their contact (e.g. as solo entrepreneur) without opting out

SI.callerid_rules: The law explicitly requires consent for automated calling and fax marketing:. By omission
SI.regime_b2c_text: There are no specific rules prohibiting live person-to-person telemarketing calls to consumers in Slovenia. Unsolicited calls with a human operator are generally allowed (opt-out regime de facto). However, the use of automated calling machines or recorded messages is strictly forbidden without prior consent:.
SI.regime_b2b_text: No special legislation for B2B telemarketing; such calls are allowed unless objected to

ES.callerid_rules: if the consumer is on Lista Robinson (or has objected)
ES.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing calls to consumers are allowed unless the person has opted out, for example through the Robinson List (Spain’s DNC list). Marketers must not call individuals who have registered their objection::.
ES.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to business contacts is generally allowed. Employees can also register their personal or work numbers on the Robinson list to opt out of marketing:
ES.notes_for_product: but currently no dedicated prefix is mandated aside from not misusing certain number ranges.

sources.title: Caller ID must be presented. Spain considered special prefixes (in 2020 a proposal for telemarketing prefix ‘+34 902’ or similar)

SE.callerid_rules: but DPA recommends informing; consent if recording for secondary uses)
SE.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is allowed unless the consumer has registered their number on the NIX register (opt-out)::. Telemarketers must not call NIX-listed individuals without explicit consent. Sweden thus follows an opt-out regime enforced by self-regulation.
SE.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is permitted. If the call is clearly in connection to the recipient’s professional role or a company contact

sources.title: NIX opt-out does not cover calls for market research

CH.callerid_rules: Not specified (common practice: business hours on weekdays)
CH.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is allowed unless the consumer has indicated their number is not to receive marketing calls. In practice, Swiss consumers can add an asterisk (*) in phone directories to opt out of sales calls:. Telemarketers are legally obliged to check directory listings and avoid calling *-marked numbers (opt-out system).
CH.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to businesses is allowed. The * opt-out system primarily applies to private individuals’ numbers. Companies’ main lines can be called
CH.notes_for_product: If the consumer has expressly consented to marketing calls

dnc.name: opt-out
dnc.url: Phone Directory Asterisk (""*"" marker in directories)

sources.title: but not for new marketing if the customer opted out.

GB.callerid_rules: Calls made purely for market research (no selling) are not covered by PECR’s marketing rules. Also
GB.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing calls to individuals (consumers, sole traders, some partnerships) are allowed only if the person has not opted out. The Telephone Preference Service (TPS) is the official opt-out list – it is illegal to call any residential number on TPS without specific consent::.
GB.regime_b2b_text: Telemarketing to companies (corporate bodies) is allowed unless the number is registered on the Corporate TPS (CTPS)::. B2B calls to corporate entities do not require prior consent, but must cease if the organization opts out via CTPS or directly.

sources.title: enforcement has increased. In 2023–2024 the ICO issued large fines for firms ignoring TPS::. The UK government announced plans (2023) to outlaw cold calls for financial products

IS.callerid_rules: No special prefix rules. Caller identity must be disclosed; hiding or misrepresenting caller ID is not allowed (general truth-in-calling obligations)
IS.regime_b2c_text: B2C: Unsolicited telemarketing prohibited without prior consent (opt-in regime). Calls to consumers require explicit consent unless consumer has opted in in advance
IS.regime_b2b_text: B2B: No specific prohibition on B2B calls found – calls to businesses allowed without prior consent but good practice is to honor objections and comply with personal data rules

dnc.name: No formal national DNC list (opt-out) – consumers may register a no-contact preference via phone directory or national registry (bannskrá)

NO.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be concealed. Norway requires telemarketers to display a valid phone number and identify the caller and source of any obtained contact data. No dedicated prefix but calls from certain number series may be recognized as telemarketing
NO.regime_b2c_text: B2C: Telemarketing to consumers allowed on an opt-out basis. Consumers can register in the Central Marketing Exclusion Register (Reservasjonsregisteret) to opt out of calls. Marketers must check the register and avoid calling opted-out numbers
NO.regime_b2b_text: B2B: Telemarketing to business contacts is generally permitted without prior consent. Calls to natural persons at businesses are allowed unless the person has opted out with that business or requested no calls

dnc.name: Reservasjonsregisteret – Central Do Not Call opt-out list (administered by Brønnøysund)

CY.callerid_rules: No special caller ID prefix. Caller must identify themselves and purpose at the start of the call. Hiding caller number is forbidden under general telecom rules
CY.regime_b2c_text: B2C: Opt-in regime – Unsolicited marketing calls to individuals are prohibited without prior consent. Direct calling for promotion requires the consumer's explicit consent in advance
CY.regime_b2b_text: B2B: No specific prohibition on B2B cold calls in legislation. Generally calls to companies or professionals are allowed without prior consent. Marketers must stop if a business contact objects (implied opt-out)

dnc.name: None (No official DNC registry – not needed due to opt-in requirement)

LI.callerid_rules: No special prefix required by law (Switzerland plans distinct prefixes for telemarketing but not yet in Liechtenstein). Caller ID must be visible; blocking or spoofing caller identity is prohibited by general telecom rules
LI.regime_b2c_text: B2C: Opt-out regime similar to Swiss/EU practice. Telemarketing calls to individuals are allowed unless the person has opted out (e.g. marked with a "Do Not Call" indicator in the phone directory). Cold calls are legal but must cease if consumer's number is flagged or if they object
LI.regime_b2b_text: B2B: No specific B2B telemarketing restrictions noted. Calls to companies or professionals are generally permitted without prior consent. Treat personal numbers at businesses as you would consumer numbers (honor any opt-out markings or requests)

dnc.name: No central DNC registry. Consumers rely on phone directory opt-out ("star" listing) or Switzerland's Robinson list to signal no telemarketing
dnc.url: N/A (Opt-out handled via telephone directory and Swiss Robinson list)

MC.callerid_rules: No special caller ID or prefix rules in force. Telemarketers should not conceal their number; France's model of using designated prefixes for marketing calls may be adopted in the future
MC.confidence: monaco currently has minimal telemarketing-specific regulation so an opt-out approach is used de facto. you can call consumers but due to public pressure monaco will likely adopt stricter rules soon. it's advisable to apply french standards
MC.regime_b2c_text: B2C: Opt-out (current) – Monaco has no dedicated telemarketing law yet. Unsolicited consumer calls are allowed by default (following French practice pre-2023) unless the consumer has objected. Many Monaco residents rely on France's Bloctel DNC list to reduce calls but Monaco itself has not implemented an official list
MC.regime_b2b_text: B2B: Allowed – No specific B2B telemarketing regulations in Monaco. Calls to businesses are generally permitted without consent. Standard data protection principles apply (cease if a person requests no further calls)

dnc.name: None (No national DNC registry as of 2025. Consumers may use France's Bloctel list informally but Monaco hasn't established its own)

SM.callerid_rules: No local caller ID rules. It's advisable to show a valid number and follow Italy's lead on prefix usage (Italy now assigns special prefixes for telemarketing calls) to avoid call blocking
SM.regime_b2c_text: B2C: Likely opt-out (no evidence of an opt-in law). San Marino law doesn't explicitly address telemarketing calls; by default unsolicited calls are allowed until the individual objects. It's safe to mirror EU/Italian practices: assume consumers haven't consented unless they opt out via a service
SM.regime_b2b_text: B2B: Allowed – No specific prohibition on B2B telemarketing. Calls to organizations or professionals are permissible without prior consent. Standard rule: stop if the business or contact objects

dnc.name: None specifically for San Marino. Residents likely rely on Italy's Registro Pubblico delle Opposizioni (public opt-out register) to block calls though SM numbers are outside its formal scope

AND.callerid_rules: No specific caller ID or prefix rules. Do not hide your number; follow standard telecom norms (Andorran numbers use +376 code – no special telemarketing prefix in use)
AND.confidence: andorra's telemarketing regime is inferred from its general data protection and consumer laws. there is no formal opt-in requirement for calls so an opt-out approach applies. always offer the recipient an easy way to refuse future calls. because there's no dnc list maintain an internal do-not-call list for andorra. adhere to gdpr principles
AND.regime_b2c_text: B2C: Opt-out (assumed) – Andorra has no dedicated telemarketing law publicly available. Direct marketing falls under data protection rules. Unsolicited calls to consumers appear to be allowed unless the person has objected (no prior consent mandate is documented). It is prudent to obtain consent when feasible given GDPR-like principles
AND.regime_b2b_text: B2B: Allowed – No special B2B telemarketing regulations found. Cold calls to businesses are generally acceptable. Treat personal data of contacts in line with legitimate interest and honor any request to stop

US.callerid_rules: Caller ID must be truthful per FCC rules

CA.regime_b2b_text: B2B exempt unless consumer contacts involved

MX.callerid_rules: Caller ID truthful per IFT rules
MX.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

GT.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

CR.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

PA.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

JM.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

AR.callerid_rules: No specific caller ID prefixes mandated nationally.
AR.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing regulated via national DNC
AR.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

BO.callerid_rules: No national caller ID/telemarketing prefixes identified.
BO.regime_b2c_text: No specific consumer telemarketing regime found.
BO.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

BR.callerid_rules: 0303 prefix requirement revoked (Aug 2025); Anatel implementing STIR/SHAKEN authenticated/identified calling (Origem Verificada).
BR.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing partially regulated (sector DNC; anti-spoofing/authenticated calls)
BR.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

CL.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing identified via mandatory prefixes; per-company opt-out via SERNAC
CL.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

CO.callerid_rules: Caller ID prefix not mandated; CRC advancing anti-spam controls.
CO.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing regulated; hours fixed by Ley 2300/2023
CO.regime_b2b_text: Mixed/Unclear for B2B (treat contacts to individuals as B2C)

EC.callerid_rules: ARCOTEL mandates identifiable numbers for such calls.
EC.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing restricted: identification & prior express consent required for commercial/publicity/proselitist calls
EC.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

GY.callerid_rules: No specific national caller ID/telemarketing prefixes identified.
GY.regime_b2c_text: No specific consumer telemarketing regime found.
GY.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

PY.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

PE.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing prohibited without prior consent (Ley 32323/2025)
PE.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

SR.regime_b2c_text: No specific consumer telemarketing regime found.
SR.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

UY.callerid_rules: “No Llame” national; no special prefixes mandated.
UY.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing regulated via national DNC
UY.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

VE.regime_b2c_text: No specific consumer telemarketing/DNC regime found.
VE.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

ZA.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be withheld
ZA.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing regulated under CPA and ECT Act
ZA.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found

NG.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing restricted under NCC Do-Not-Disturb Directive

KE.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be spoofed
KE.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing regulated under Data Protection Act

GH.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be spoofed

UG.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing under Data Protection and Privacy Act

RW.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be spoofed
RW.regime_b2c_text: Marketing calls under Data Protection Law 2021

SN.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be hidden

CI.callerid_rules: Caller ID must not be spoofed

CM.regime_b2c_text: Data Protection framework limited no specific telemarketing law

AO.regime_b2c_text: Consumer telemarketing under Data Protection Law 2011

BW.regime_b2c_text: Data Protection Act 2018 applies to marketing

NA.regime_b2c_text: Data Protection Bill pending; no DNC yet

EG.regime_b2c_text: NTRA regulates promotional/commercial calls (registration & caller identification)
EG.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

MA.regime_b2c_text: General consumer (Law 31-08) & telecom law; no specific telemarketing/DNC
MA.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

DZ.regime_b2c_text: General consumer & e-commerce framework; no telemarketing/DNC
DZ.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

TN.regime_b2c_text: Data-protection law bans processing for advertising without express consent
TN.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

SD.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

LY.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found.

AU.callerid_rules: Caller ID must be provided (telemarketers number for return contact); no special prefix required
AU.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers regulated under Do Not Call Register Act 2006 and ACMA industry standards
AU.regime_b2b_text: Business calls largely exempt from DNC; only general calling standards (hours ID) apply

NZ.callerid_rules: Valid caller ID should be displayed (NZ Telco Code bars spoofing); no special prefix required for telemarketing.
NZ.regime_b2c_text: No specific telemarketing statute; governed by overlapping laws (Privacy Act 2020) and self-regulation. Industry-run Do Not Call list for consumers. Fair Trading Act covers uninvited direct sales (5-day cooling-off written contract)
NZ.regime_b2b_text: No special regulation for B2B telemarketing; business numbers cannot register on DNC (general consumer protections dont apply to business contacts)

dnc.name: Marketing Association Do Not Call Registry

FJ.callerid_rules: Not specified (no known caller ID requirements; advisable not to block CLI)
FJ.confidence: without clear regulations apply conservative standards
FJ.regime_b2c_text: No specific telemarketing or DNC legislation. Telemarketing falls under general consumer protection and telecom confidentiality obligations. No requirement for prior consent to call identified.
FJ.regime_b2b_text: No dedicated B2B calling rules; B2B telemarketing is unregulated beyond normal business practice.

PG.callerid_rules: Not specified; telemarketers typically should provide a callback number (no special prefix mandated).
PG.regime_b2c_text: No specific telemarketing laws. Telemarketing practices are subject to general consumer law (Fair Practices Act) and telecom regulations. No national DNC registry.
PG.regime_b2b_text: No targeted B2B rules; B2B telemarketing is generally unregulated.

WS.callerid_rules: Not specified (no mandated caller ID rules; best practice is to show a working number).
WS.regime_b2c_text: No dedicated telemarketing law or DNC list. Telemarketing is governed only by general provisions (e.g. Telecommunications Act 2005 confidentiality and consumer protection laws).
WS.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing rules identified.

TO.callerid_rules: Not specified; recommended to send a valid caller number (no special prefix mandated).
TO.confidence: ensure an internal dnc process – if a tongan consumer opts out do not call again. adhere to polite calling times (e.g. daytime on weekdays). without regulation rely on consent and courtesy
TO.regime_b2c_text: No known telemarketing-specific regulations. General communications and consumer laws apply; no official DNC registry.

KI.callerid_rules: Not specified (provide caller ID as good practice).
KI.confidence: follow standard opt-out and disclosure practices. in absence of law treat all contacts respectfully
KI.regime_b2c_text: No specific laws for telemarketing. Kiribati has no known DNC list or marketing-specific regulation; only broad consumer protection and telecom service rules apply.

TV.confidence: adopt general best practices as law is silent
TV.regime_b2c_text: No telemarketing-specific legal regime. No DNC registry or explicit requirements identified.

VU.regime_b2c_text: No explicit telemarketing regulation. Telecom law contains privacy provisions (cannot collect or share user info without consent) but no telemarketing-specific rules or DNC list.

MH.regime_b2c_text: No known telemarketing regulations. The Marshall Islands do not maintain a DNC registry; telemarketing governed only by general advertising and consumer protection principles.

FM.regime_b2c_text: No specific telemarketing or DNC laws in FSM. Consumer contacts by phone are subject only to general fair practice standards.

PW.regime_b2c_text: No telemarketing law or DNC list in Palau. Only general consumer protection and privacy expectations apply.

NR.regime_b2c_text: No telemarketing regulations. Nauru has no DNC list; only general provisions (if any) against harassment or misuse of telecommunications apply.
